segments.text: This is a History 374 project for Dr. Anderson's class in the fall of 1984.
Speak to you there.
And we'll be talking with a man.
His name is Vic Mazufi.
Vic Mazufi, who went to Peru in 1971 through 1974 as a Peace Corps volunteer.
And Vic, you want to tell us a little bit about your background as far as your education?
Were you born maybe a little bit?
Yeah, I grew up in Northwest New Jersey and graduated from high school and attended Georgetown University in Washington.
I was a language major there.
Spanish was my major.
And on graduation, I'd always been interested in Latin America.
And I saw Peace Corps as a vehicle sort of to travel and to gain a little experience down there and perhaps get a better idea of what I want to do in the future.
It was accepted upon application, and about a month after graduation, we went into training.
It was a three-month training program, starting out in Vermont, and then to Mexico and finally Hawaii for some technical training in rice production.
And then about two weeks of in-country training in Peru, and we were finally sent to our sites.
OK, but that was in 1971, correct?
1971, the latter part of 1971.
OK, how did you go about getting there?
Did you fly?
Did you drive?
Oh, no.
It was a group of about 34 volunteers.
And we were flown down.
I believe we left from Miami International Airport and flew right to the airport.
OK. What all did you take?
What did they tell you?
Did they give you a list of certain things you could take?
Basic clothing.
I was in a coastal semi-arid climate, so there wasn't a lot of heavy clothing that needed to be taken.
Technical references, textbooks, and other material that was provided during the Peace Corps training.
Things we need in the field later on as far as technical material.
A lot of extra reading material just for the
The times that you're alone or you need to relax.
But you have your supplies for your kitchen and your bedding and all could be acquired in the country, so there's no problem with really burdening yourself with a whole lot of extra baggage.
Were you by a major city or anything while you were there?
I was about 10 minutes away from a city of about 200,000 people, although I was located in a town of about 3,000 to 4,000 people, a small rural ag community.
Okay.
What was your first impression as you...
Maybe you got off the plane and you got to your site.
As I got to my site, a lot of dust.
A lot of dust.
And it was hot, dry, because it was on the desert.
I think the whole three years I was there, I believe it rained about a total of maybe two inches in three years.
Three inches?
Yeah.
Okay.
What did your average day consist of there in the rice?
Well, it depends.
When I first got there, it was a matter of getting to know the people, getting to know the farmers, the problems, the people I was working with.
The work they involved over a period of time at first was just getting familiar with the site.
And then as I became familiar with the site and the work I was trying to do and the farmers I was working with,

A typical work day, say, six to eight months down the road, once I felt at ease there, going out and visiting individual farmers in the field, discussing with them some of the work we've been doing and what problems they may be having, and trying to work out some kind of a solution, make formative recommendations to whatever problem they may have had.
Is there any isolated experiences that may be good or bad that stick out in your mind?
that you carry with you?
I wouldn't say any particular isolated incidents.
A lot of minor things, but nothing that really would stand out.
Just the overall experience and the sense of accomplishment after the job is done.
We haven't gone into it yet, but the work I was actually doing was the introduction of an improved rice variety to the local rice farmers in the Santa Valley.

Over a period of three years after installing test plots and the farmers learning how to grow this particular variety and seeing the results it had and that it was outperforming the traditional variety that had been growing for many years, seeing that they were changing over to this new variety we were trying to introduce and accepting it and growing it and having very good results, the yield was increased.
not double, but at least by a good 30 to 40 percent.
The grain quality was much better than the traditional variety they'd been growing.
The vegetative period was a lot shorter, so it gave them time for a double crop.
They were cropping, intercropping with peas and beans, so their income was increased.
And just the fact that I saw a lot of people responding to the efforts we've been making in introducing this variety,
and planting it, and eventually the variety was, had replaced the traditional variety by the time I had left.
It was a predominant variety in that valley.
Did the farmers, did they welcome you into their fields?
Were they kind of...
They welcomed me, but with a certain bit of skepticism.
I was a Yankee, a young gringo.
And sometimes they use that term.
Did they respect your education?
Yeah, but they still wanted me to prove myself.
And I learned as I went.
I made a few mistakes in the beginning.
And I tried to disguise them as well as I could.
But I think overall, over time, the confidence that I displayed, I think they accepted it.
And they came to trust me and to believe that I had the confidence.
to show them a few new ideas or techniques.
Did they believe in American education?

The thing is, yeah, they had an assumption that Americans, yes, were well-educated and should know what they were talking about, but it comes down to an individual one-to-one relationship where you have to prove yourself to that farmer and gain their trust.
Once you gain the trust, then
Whether they respect you or not will come, but they have to trust you first before they'll open up and you can be more sincere with them and try to teach if you can.
But the thing is, the whole time I was there, I think I was learning more from them than I was actually able to teach.
But it's the ideas, the...

techniques that i was picking up from the whole spectrum of farmers in that area and getting an idea of the proper techniques to use and then focusing on farmers that had problems individual farmers that were not as managing the crops as well as the better ones and bringing those better ideas to the farmers that i saw were marginal that that needed help okay what was the basic uh economy that time in peru was it pretty poor
Did a few people control a lot of the aristocratic?
Yeah, it was, but just before I got there.
But I got there soon as the, there was a military coup in 1968.
And it was a leftist military dictatorship that took over the country.
And what they tried to do was expropriate a lot of the large land holdings and turn it back over to the former owners in the form of a agricultural production co-op.
They did this not only in agriculture, but in industry.
The steel industry was expropriated from private ownership and turned back over to the workers.
The fishing industry was one of the biggest industries in Peru, and a lot of the light industry as well.
And it was in a state of flux the whole time I was there.
New owners, a lot of government intervention, poor planning, poor management.
Production went down a lot in the steel industry, the fishing industry.
Not only because of the management problems, but because of changes in weather patterns and ocean currents.
The anchovy, which was the main fish that they were harvesting, sort of disappeared for a few years.
And they lost a lot of their foreign exchange because of that.
And agriculture production went down because of the co-ops.
A lot of the social and technical problems they were having and the transformation of ownership.
The economy was relatively poor.
It's a developing country and a relatively poor country.
Is there a significant class structure?
Yeah, there was.
Yes, there's a very small class structure.

upper class and a very large lower class with a minimal middle class which this is mainly viewed your merchants and retailers and some of your industrial workers but it's the bulk of the population is agricultural and poor okay did any problems that was that were occurring in chile right uh at that time period down there with uh allende
Did that affect you in any way in Peru?
Were the people aware of it in Peru?
Yes, it came out in the Peruvian press.
And the press wasn't controlled, but the press was favorable towards the government.
And being elected as government, they were aligned, if not politically, then idealistically with Allende's government.
And when Allende was overthrown, it came out that there were CIA implications helping to overthrow him.
a lot of people became, well, they always suspected, a lot of people suspected that maybe the Peace Corps volunteers were involved with the CIA.
And because of the events in Chile,
It just brought up to the surface a little more that perhaps the CIA may be getting involved in improving politics, and we could have been perhaps puppets.
It was in a lot of conversations that came out.

Yeah, yeah, but you're involved, and it took a lot of convincing, and I'm not sure we convinced everyone, but I think a lot of people... Once they gained that trust... Yeah, I think they realized and tried to
quite the more radical elements that were in the field with us working that, you know, just a guy doing a job and let's not harass him too much.
But there were always some that did actually believe that we worked.
But I doubt, and I can't say for sure, but it's always been Peace Corps policy never to be involved in political activities.
And being involved with the CIA would jeopardize Peace Corps operations throughout the world.
How about just interested in the cocaine business there in Peru?
Was it still a major export?
No, no.
When I was there, cocaine really hadn't gained as much popularity as it has now.
The coca leaf, which is cultivated in the mountains, is utilized a lot by the laborers, a lot by the Indians in the mountains.

A lot of people, a lot of the farmers I worked with, I'd go out to the fields and they'd have a mouthful, like we have here in Texas, they'd have a mouthful of tobacco or Copenhagen, they'd have a mouthful of coca leaves.
And it didn't have the same effect as purified cocaine, but it was a narcotic and I guess it allowed them to work a little bit harder and not experience hunger and thirst.
It was, but it wasn't.
As a matter of fact, the trade in coca leaves was legal at the time.
Okay.
Upon your completion of your three-year tour, I guess, or whatever you could call it, did you feel that you, was it a success in your life?
Did you, or I guess put it this way, what kind of impact did it play on your life?
Did you feel like you had done something?
Yeah, yeah, definitely.
A lot of Peace Corps programs in different countries, especially when Peace Corps initially started, they'd send a volunteer out to the field in an unstructured job.
They had a kind of a catch-all phrase for the work they did, which was community development.
And it was up to the volunteer himself to either build a school or teach English or maybe get small community gardens started, vegetable gardens.
Whereas my job was more structured, and we had a definite
a job to do and a definite goal to obtain.
I think by the time I left, and I've been back there since, I've seen the results of it.
Most of the farmers have been.
Most, if not all, the farmers in that area do grow the variety that I introduced when I was there.
And that's a great satisfaction.
I've seen the results.
And not only that, before I went into Peace Corps, I was sort of undecided about what I wanted to do in the future.
It kind of got me more interested in agriculture.
As a result, I came back to Hanover and got my master's in ag.
I kind of have a profession I want to pursue now.
Well, going back to the start, back in the early 60s, Kennedy initiated the Peace Corps program.
When did you first hear about the Peace Corps?
I mean, when you very first heard about it was the Kennedy idealism period.
Yeah, I'd heard about it since, you know, since junior high school, I was aware of it.

And throughout college, you would hear more because there were recruiters on campus, and you were running into people who had been overseas, had been in the Peace Corps, and some of those had very favorable experiences.
And I thought it, you know, it started getting me interested.
And, yeah, at the time, people, a lot of the people...
They were very idealistic, and they thought maybe they could do something to change the status in society, if not overseas.
And I think that's one of the reasons Kennedy created it.
He saw there was a desire among young people to do something besides worry about themselves.
And he gave them an outlet to do that.
He challenged them or something.
I guess you could call it that.
The purpose of the Peace Corps wasn't only to give young people an opportunity to do something a little extra, but we were sort of like goodwill ambassadors.
I mean, you gave people in the Third World an opportunity to meet Americans.
This common, ordinary American youth, you got the idea that you weren't the spies and the exploiters and
the capitalists that the Third World had made us out to be, especially the radical types in the Third World.
I think, for the most part, volunteers betray that, that we're willing to help and we're not simply out for a buck, because the pay we got
It was just a subsistence allowance.
You know, you got by.
It took it easy.
You could save a little, but that wasn't the purpose.
It was just enough to allow you to live comfortably.
That's about it.
And I think a lot of people, at least from my experience, I don't have to say they were impressed with the Americans that they were dealing with.
I think it was a favorable experience on both parts, mine and theirs.
I got to be friends with an awful lot of crewmates in the area I was working, and I think the respect that was generated was mutual.

Okay, Vic, upon your three years there, did you feel like you had accomplished what you set out to do, or did you feel like you maybe needed six months to a year to maybe accomplish what you set out to do?
Well, basically, I feel I accomplished what I set out to do.
But because I've been there three years and the experience gained over those three years, I think I could have done perhaps a little better as far as providing technical assistance to these farmers.
But after being there three years, I had to apply for a fourth year extension.
Soon after that application was made, we were notified by the Peruvian government that we'd have to leave the country.
We were given 90 days.
The Peace Corps program was given 90 days to leave the country.
And it was, I believe it was a political decision.
Maybe the events in Chile had something to do with it, maybe not.
But in 1974, there was a lot of talk about
especially in the press and political cartoons, about the Peace Corps being involved with the CIA.
And the Proving Government seemed to be one over the country of all foreign influence.
The Rotary Club, the Boy Scouts, and the Peace Corps was one of the biggest organizations that was first asked to lead.
And it came as a shock to myself and to the program in general, most of the people involved.
A lot of volunteers were in service a year or two, and seeing results of the work they were doing and having to leave it at midstream was disheartening, to say the least.
And, well, there was nothing we could do.
Requests were made, but all immediately turned down by the Peruvian government.
So I left with a bit of disappointment in not being able to spend a fourth year there and perhaps doing a bit more
in the field I was working.
But that was just the way it turned out.
OK, one last question for the people out there.
The Peace Corps as a whole, you think it's a worthwhile program?
Did you get a lot out of it?
You think that it's just a good program?
Yeah, I do, especially now because they're not recruiting the generalists they were when the Peace Corps initially started.
They want people with a skill or a trait that they can teach.

If not, they want people with a technical background, a good college education in agriculture or some engineering field, because a lot of the countries are requesting people with more technical skills.
I'd recommend Peace Corps to anybody that's interested in working overseas.
It was a great cross-cultural experience for me, and I think it would be for anyone.
At the same time,
It tests your abilities, your ability at innovation and resourcefulness and adapting.
Because that's a big part of it.
It's the ability to adapt to the global conditions and the people and the culture you're working in.
And it's a necessity if you're going to be successful.
Well, Vic, I appreciate you taking the time and letting me interview you.
And I think this is going to be a worthwhile pay to let people
listen to it, and learn a little bit about the Peace Corps and Peru itself.
Appreciate it, dude.
Thank you, Jim.
